‚ÄúWhat are the 5 Most Common Malignant Tumors of the Oral Cavity?‚Äù Quick Review #204 - #pathology #oralpathology #doctorgallagher #oralsurgery #oralsurgeon #dentist #dentistry #dental #oralcancer #cancer #tumor The top 5 most common malignant tumors of the oral cavity, listed from least common to most common incidence, along with their approximate percentage of incidence, are as follows: 5. Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma (ACC) ‚Ä¢ Incidence: Approximately 1-2% of malignant oral cavity tumors. ‚Ä¢ Description: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a rare malignant tumor typically found in the minor salivary glands within the oral cavity. It is known for its slow growth but aggressive behavior, including perineural invasion. 4. Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma ‚Ä¢ Incidence: Approximately 2-3% of malignant oral cavity tumors. ‚Ä¢ Description: This is the most common malignant salivary gland tumor, which can also occur within the oral cavity. It exhibits a wide range of biological behavior, from low-grade to high-grade malignancy. 3. Lymphoma ‚Ä¢ Incidence: Approximately 3-5% of malignant oral cavity tumors. ‚Ä¢ Description: Lymphomas in the oral cavity are usually non-Hodgkin types and can arise from lymphoid tissue within the oral mucosa. They are relatively uncommon but represent a significant portion of oral malignancies. 2. Verrucous Carcinoma ‚Ä¢ Incidence: Approximately 5-10% of malignant oral cavity tumors. ‚Ä¢ Description: Verrucous carcinoma is a low-grade variant of squamous cell carcinoma that typically presents as a slow-growing, warty lesion. It has a good prognosis with a low tendency for metastasis. 1. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) ‚Ä¢ Incidence: Approximately 90-95% of malignant oral cavity tumors. ‚Ä¢ Description: Squamous cell carcinoma is by far the most common malignant tumor of the oral cavity, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It can arise from various sites within the oral cavity, including the tongue, floor of the mouth, and buccal mucosa. SCC has a variable prognosis depending on the stage at diagnosis and treatment response. These percentages are approximate and can vary slightly depending on the specific population or study referenced. References: 1. Moreno-Garc√≠a, C. (2016). Elective neck dissection in early oral squamous cell carcinoma: Necessary? Plastic and Aesthetic Research, 3(167-174). https://lnkd.in/d2MKh_DG 2. Barnes, L., Eveson, J. W., Reichart, P., & Sidransky, D. (2005). World Health Organization classification of tumours: Pathology and genetics of head and neck tumours (3rd ed.). IARC Press. 3. Neville, B. W., Damm, D. D., Allen, C. M., & Chi, A. C. (2015). Oral and maxillofacial pathology (4th ed.). Saunders. 4. Johnson, N. W., Jayasekara, P., & Amarasinghe, A. A. H. K. (2011). Squamous cell carcinoma and precursor lesions of the oral cavity: Epidemiology and aetiology. Periodontology 2000, 57(1), 19-37. https://lnkd.in/dmQCZ_Sj. 5. ChatGPT.2024.

Full Podcast: ‚ÄúChoosing Oral Surgery, Tips for Acing Exams, Work-Life Balance, Botox for TMJ/TMD, 4-Year vs 6-Year Oral Surgery Residency‚Äù Podcast Link: https://lnkd.in/eY86CeDp YouTube Link: https://lnkd.in/ePXSZWqV Top 3 Viewers on this Episode on TikTok LIVE Q&A #27: 1st - @hhm1229 2nd - @maryrichardson91 3rd - @ronald.chennn 1. Questions Asked: 02:42 - Did you know in dental school you'd want to go to OMFS? 06:43 - What were your biggest factors that played a role in your dental school admissions? 07:59 - What are some last-minute tips for taking the DAT, especially the day before the exam? 08:30 - Were you ever between medical and dental school after discovering your interest in surgery? 08:45 - Is there a difference between research hours and shadowing hours? 08:59 - What would you do study-wise the day before the exam? 09:11 - Tips for OMFS interviews this fall? 10:01 - Thoughts on using Botox for TMJ/TMD? 10:45 - Does paid assisting count as shadowing hours, or are they separate? 11:03 - Are four-year dental programs more competitive than six-year programs? 12:03 - How did you study in dental school? 12:40 - Is Quizlet better than Anki? 2. Topics & Stories: 02:01 - Preparing for Dental School Admissions and the DAT. 02:42 - Choosing Oral Surgery as a Specialty. 06:43 - Tips for Exam Preparation. 07:59 - Interviewing for OMFS Programs. 09:11 - Using Botox for TMJ/TMD. 11:03 - Competitiveness of Four-Year vs. Six-Year Dental Programs. 12:03 - Work-Life Balance in the Dental Profession. 12:15 - Study Techniques in Dental School: Quizlet vs. Anki. 3. Quotes & Inspiration, Motivation, and Wisdom 02:42 - "I shadowed an oral surgeon prior to starting dental school, and I knew I was very interested... During dental school, it solidified it 100%." 06:43 - "The day before the exam, definitely get a lot of carbs in, store up some energy, and get a great night's sleep... You're going to want to get up and your mind be in it." 08:30 - "It was disappointing that I felt like I let [my mentor] down, but I can't feel comfortable in going into a DSO. I need to get into private practice prior to exploring DSO and corporate options." 09:11 - "Botox is a conservative measure, a non-surgical approach, that can help relieve pressure and stress... but remember Botox doesn't last forever; it lasts about three to four months." 11:03 - "With rising tuition and loans, people don't want to spend extra years getting their MD when they're not going to use it 99% of the time in oral surgery." 12:03 - "Work-life balance is serious... You have to be intentional about how you manage it." 12:40 - "Quizlet was extremely helpful for me... That's how you remember it, by seeing the photo." Now available on: - Dr. Gallagher‚Äôs Podcast & YouTube Channel - TikTok LIVE Q&A Session #27 Watch worn in this episode = Citizen Caliber 2100 Limited Edition Panda 8.14.24

‚ÄúWhat are Osteogenesis Imperfecta & Dentinogenesis Imperfecta?‚Äù Quick Review #203 - #pathology #oralpathology #doctorgallagher #oralsurgery #oralsurgeon #dentist #dentistry #dental #osteogenesisimperfecta #dentinogenesisimperfecta Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that break easily, often with little or no apparent cause. The condition is caused by a defect in the production of collagen, a protein that is crucial for maintaining the strength and structure of bones. The severity of OI can vary widely, ranging from mild cases with few fractures to severe cases where fractures occur frequently and can lead to significant physical disabilities. There are several types of OI, with Type I being the mildest and Type II being the most severe. Dentinogenesis imperfecta (DI) is a genetic disorder that affects the development of dentin, the hard tissue beneath the enamel of the teeth. In individuals with DI, the dentin is poorly formed, leading to discolored, fragile teeth that are prone to wear, breakage, and decay. The teeth often have an opalescent or translucent appearance, and the enamel may chip away easily due to the underlying dentin‚Äôs weakness. Relationship between Osteogenesis Imperfecta and Dentinogenesis Imperfecta: Yes, osteogenesis imperfecta and dentinogenesis imperfecta are related. Dentinogenesis imperfecta can occur as a part of osteogenesis imperfecta, particularly in certain types of OI, such as Type I and Type IV. When DI occurs in the context of OI, it is often referred to as ‚ÄúDentinogenesis Imperfecta associated with Osteogenesis Imperfecta‚Äù or ‚ÄúDI Type I‚Äù. This condition arises from mutations in the same genes (COL1A1 or COL1A2) that are responsible for producing type I collagen, which is crucial for both bone and dentin formation. Thus, the defective collagen impacts both the skeletal system and the teeth, leading to the characteristic features of both OI and DI in affected individuals. In contrast, ‚ÄúDentinogenesis Imperfecta Type II‚Äù and ‚ÄúType III‚Äù occur independently of OI and are caused by mutations in the DSPP gene, which specifically affects dentin development. These types do not involve the bones and are not associated with osteogenesis imperfecta. References: 1. ResearchGate. (n.d.). Dentinogenesis imperfecta. The primary teeth are severely abraded. Enamel is breaking away from the incisal edge of the lower permanent central incisors [Image]. 2. Marini, J. C., Forlino, A., Cabral, W. A., Barnes, A. M., San Antonio, J. D., Milgrom, S., ‚Ä¶ & Antoniazzi, F. (2017). Consortium for osteogenesis imperfecta mutations in the procollagen type I genes and related collagenopathies: Phenotypic variability and pathogenesis. Human Mutation, 38(11), 1624-1637. 3. Sillence, D. O. (2003). Osteogenesis imperfecta: An expanding panorama of variants. Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research, 411, 11-24. 4. ChatGPT.2024.

‚ÄúWhat is the Recurrence Rate of Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma in the Oral Cavity?‚Äù Quick Review #202 - #pathology #oralpathology #doctorgallagher #oralsurgery #oralsurgeon #dentist #dentistry #dental #adenocarcinoma #adenoidcysticadenocarcinoma Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the oral cavity is known for its propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis, particularly to the lungs. The recurrence rates for ACC can vary significantly depending on several factors, including the presence or absence of perineural invasion (PNI). 1. Without Perineural Invasion (PNI): ‚Ä¢ The recurrence rate for ACC without perineural invasion tends to be lower, although the exact percentage can vary depending on the study. On average, the local recurrence rate in cases without PNI is around 20-30% over a 5 to 10-year period. 2. With Perineural Invasion (PNI): ‚Ä¢ ACC with perineural invasion has a significantly higher recurrence rate due to the tumor‚Äôs ability to spread along nerve pathways. The recurrence rate in cases with PNI can range from 50-70% over a similar 5 to 10-year period, making PNI a poor prognostic indicator. These figures highlight the aggressive nature of ACC, particularly when PNI is present, emphasizing the importance of early detection and comprehensive treatment to minimize the risk of recurrence. References: 1. Garc√≠a-Sevilla, M., Moreta-Mart√≠nez, R., Garc√≠a-Mato, D., Arenas de Frutos, G., Ochanindiano, S., Navarro-Cu√©llar, C., Sanju√°n de Moreta, G., & Pascau, J. (2022). Surgical navigation, augmented reality, and 3D printing for hard palate adenoid cystic carcinoma en-bloc resection: Case report and literature review. Frontiers in Oncology, 11, Article 741191. https://lnkd.in/ea4uehYm 2. Fordice, J., Kershaw, C., El-Naggar, A., & Goepfert, H. (1999). Adenoid cystic carcinoma of the head and neck: Predictors of morbidity and mortality. Archives of Otolaryngology‚ÄìHead & Neck Surgery, 125(2), 149-152. https://lnkd.in/eh7qJs_S 3. Kokemueller, H., Eckardt, A., Brachvogel, P., & Hausamen, J. E. (2004). Adenoid cystic carcinoma of the head and neck‚ÄîA 20 years experience. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, 33(1), 25-31. https://lnkd.in/e8RcfuSZ 4. Sung, M. W., Kim, K. H., Kim, J. W., Min, Y. G., Seong, W. J., & Park, S. W. (2003). Clinicopathologic predictors and impact of perineural invasion in adenoid cystic carcinoma of the head and neck. Head & Neck, 25(7), 618-625. https://lnkd.in/egVmfnWj 5. ChatGPT. 2024.

‚ÄúWhere is the Pterygomandibular Space?‚Äù Quick Review #201 - #surgery #surgeon #doctorgallagher #oralsurgery #oralsurgeon #omfs #dentist #dentistry #dental #pterygomandibularspace The pterygomandibular space is an important anatomical region in the oral cavity, particularly relevant for dental anesthesia and surgical procedures. Key Anatomical Landmarks: 1. Medial Pterygoid Muscle: ‚Ä¢ Forms the medial boundary of the space. ‚Ä¢ Lies adjacent to the mandible and plays a role in mastication. 2. Ramus of the Mandible: ‚Ä¢ The lateral boundary of the space. ‚Ä¢ Important for identifying the depth of the pterygomandibular space. 3. Lateral Pterygoid Muscle: ‚Ä¢ Located superiorly and plays a crucial role in jaw movement. ‚Ä¢ The muscle fibers are associated with the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). 4. Lingula of the Mandible: ‚Ä¢ A bony projection on the medial surface of the mandible. ‚Ä¢ Serves as a guide for the inferior alveolar nerve block. 5. Inferior Alveolar Nerve and Lingual Nerve: ‚Ä¢ The inferior alveolar nerve travels through the space and is a target for anesthesia. ‚Ä¢ The lingual nerve is positioned anteriorly and medially, innervating the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. 6. Pterygomandibular Raphe: ‚Ä¢ A tendinous band that serves as an attachment point for the buccinator and superior pharyngeal constrictor muscles. ‚Ä¢ A landmark for the medial approach to the space. 7. Maxillary Artery: ‚Ä¢ One of the major blood vessels that supplies the deep structures of the face. ‚Ä¢ May be encountered during surgical procedures in this space. Important Boundaries: 1. Lateral Boundary: ‚Ä¢ Formed by the medial surface of the mandibular ramus. ‚Ä¢ Provides structural support and limits the space laterally. 2. Medial Boundary: ‚Ä¢ Defined by the medial pterygoid muscle. ‚Ä¢ Contributes to the delineation of the space and influences access during procedures. 3. Superior Boundary: ‚Ä¢ Marked by the lateral pterygoid muscle. ‚Ä¢ Important for identifying the upper extent of the space. 4. Inferior Boundary: ‚Ä¢ Corresponds to the inferior border of the mandible. ‚Ä¢ This boundary is significant in determining the vertical extent of the space. 5. Anterior Boundary: ‚Ä¢ The pterygomandibular raphe and the buccinator muscle. ‚Ä¢ Provides a functional and anatomical limit to the space in the front. 6. Posterior Boundary: ‚Ä¢ Defined by the parotid gland and the posterior border of the mandible. ‚Ä¢ This boundary is crucial for understanding the relationship with adjacent structures such as the facial nerve. References: 1. Dentistry and Medicine Blogspot. (2011, September 9). Pterygomandibular abscess, anatomic location, etiology, clinical presentation and treatment. 2. Miloro, M., Ghali, G. E., Larsen, P. E., & Waite, P. (Eds.). (2022). Peterson‚Äôs principles of oral and maxillofacial surgery (4th ed.). Springer. 3. Gray, H., Standring, S., & Ellis, H. (Eds.). (2020). Gray‚Äôs anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice (42nd ed.). Elsevier. 4. ChatGPT.2024
